page.title: 03Forestry
page.content: The forests are owned by the North Yorks Moors Forest Commission. The soil is peat and research into pollen trapped in peat deposits show the forest was once composed mainly of oak, alder, elm, lime, birch, ash and hazel but at the present day the forest consists mainly of pine, spruce, larch and sycamore. The forest tree here is Sitka Spruce. It is the forester's 'bread and butter' tree of this area as it grows quickly and gives a high yield of timber. Also where it is very waterlogged, willow trees grow. The forest provides shelter for wild animals and also many quite rare wild plants and flowers grow. The Forestry Commission is responsible for the general upkeep of the forest.
